Cloud Fundamentals.title: Cloud Fundamentals
Cloud Fundamentals.description: This chapter introduces the core concepts of cloud computing, its benefits, characteristics, and deployment models.

details: Cloud computing provides on-demand access to computing resources over the internet.
Users access storage, servers, databases, networking, and software without managing hardware.
Cloud enables pay-as-you-go pricing and global scalability.
Cost-effective: no hardware purchases.
Scalability: scale up/down as needed.
High availability and global distribution.
Security and automatic updates.
On-demand self-service.
Broad network access.
Resource pooling.
Rapid elasticity.
Measured service (pay for what you use).
Public Cloud — AWS, Azure, GCP.
Private Cloud — internal to an organization.
Hybrid Cloud — combination of public and private.
Community Cloud — shared by organizations with common goals.

sections.summary: Cloud computing provides scalable, cost-effective, and reliable computing resources accessible globally.

Virtualization.title: Virtualization
Virtualization.description: Virtualization allows multiple virtual machines or containers to run on a single physical machine using hypervisors.

details: Virtualization abstracts hardware into virtual environments.
Multiple OS instances share underlying physical hardware.
Type 1 (Bare-metal): runs directly on hardware. Examples: VMware ESXi, Microsoft Hyper-V.
Type 2 (Hosted): runs on top of an OS. Examples: VirtualBox, VMware Workstation.
VMs contain OS, applications, and virtual hardware.
Offer high isolation but require more resources.
Containers share the host OS kernel.
Lightweight, fast to start, ideal for microservices.
Docker popularized container adoption.

sections.summary: Virtualization enables efficient resource use, multi-OS environments, and the foundation for cloud computing.

SaaS, PaaS, IaaS.title: SaaS, PaaS, IaaS
SaaS, PaaS, IaaS.description: This chapter explains the three major cloud service delivery models used to provide software, platforms, and infrastructure.

details: Software delivered via the internet.
Examples: Gmail, Netflix, Salesforce.
No installation or maintenance required.
Provides tools to build, deploy, and manage apps.
Examples: Firebase, Heroku, AWS Elastic Beanstalk.
Developers focus on code, not infrastructure.
Virtual servers, networking, storage on demand.
Examples: AWS EC2, Azure VM, Google Compute Engine.

sections.summary: Cloud service models provide different levels of abstraction to support development, deployment, and management.

AWS Basics.title: AWS Basics
AWS Basics.description: This chapter covers essential AWS cloud services used for compute, storage, and identity management.

details: EC2 provides scalable virtual servers.
Supports Linux/Windows instances, auto-scaling, load balancing.
Simple Storage Service for object storage.
Durable, scalable, used for backups, media, static websites.
Run code without managing servers.
Pay only for execution time.
Supports Node.js, Python, Java, Go, etc.
Manages users, roles, and permissions.
Follows least-privilege security model.

sections.summary: AWS provides robust compute, storage, and identity services used in modern cloud applications.

Azure Basics.title: Azure Basics
Azure Basics.description: Microsoft Azure offers cloud compute, storage, networking, and AI tools for enterprise workloads.

details: Virtual Machines for scalable compute.
App Service for hosting web apps.
Azure Functions for serverless workloads.
Blob Storage for unstructured data.
Queue Storage for messaging.
File and Table Storage services.

sections.summary: Azure enables enterprises to deploy scalable applications with integrated cloud tools and services.

Containers & Docker.title: Containers & Docker
Containers & Docker.description: This chapter introduces Docker containers, images, layers, and registries used for modern DevOps and deployment.

details: Lightweight environment packaging an application and dependencies.
Faster and more efficient than VMs.
Images contain the app environment.
Built using Dockerfile instructions.
Images are layered for efficiency.
Containers run images as isolated processes.
Support portability across environments.
Used to store and share images.
Examples: Docker Hub, AWS ECR, GitHub Packages.

sections.summary: Docker simplifies development, packaging, and deployment using standardized container environments.

Kubernetes.title: Kubernetes
Kubernetes.description: Kubernetes (K8s) is a container orchestration platform used to manage clusters, deployments, and scaling.

details: Master node manages cluster state.
Worker nodes run container workloads.
Components: API server, scheduler, controller, kubelet.
Pod: smallest deployable unit in K8s.
Deployment manages pod scaling and rolling updates.
Expose pods internally or externally.
Types: ClusterIP, NodePort, LoadBalancer.

sections.summary: Kubernetes automates deployment, scaling, and management of distributed containerized applications.

Cloud Security.title: Cloud Security
Cloud Security.description: This chapter covers essential cloud security practices including IAM, encryption, and network protection.

details: Use roles and policies with least-privilege access.
Multi-factor authentication improves security.
Encrypt data at rest and in transit.
Use KMS for key management.
Firewalls, VPCs, subnets, and security groups.
Protect workloads from unauthorized access.

sections.summary: Cloud security relies on access control, encryption, secure networks, and continuous monitoring.

Serverless Computing.title: Serverless Computing
Serverless Computing.description: Serverless computing executes code without provisioning or managing servers, reducing operational overhead.

details: Infrastructure is abstracted away.
Automatically scales based on traffic.
Ideal for event-driven applications.
AWS Lambda, Azure Functions, Google Cloud Functions.
You only pay when functions run.
Stateless, fast, and scalable execution.
APIs, automation scripts, ML inference, real-time notifications.
Backend for mobile/web apps.

sections.summary: Serverless simplifies deployment with auto-scaling, low cost, and minimal server management.
